history.content:
Took the class last semester in its pilot offering, would highly recommend.

To answer your questions:

Webcast: The class was not webcasted when I took the course and I would be surprised if it was webcasted since the class is heavily discussion-based.

What You Learn: The course works towards writing a blog post and news article about current research at Berkeley Engineering in order to teach students how to communicate technical work to nontechnical audiences. You'll also conduct at least 1 interview with the people involved in the research you'll write about (often the professor).

Workload: Around 3 hours a week outside class if you do the assignments thoughtfully. Much less than any R&C course, but I personally feel you get a lot more out of it. Obviously the end of the semester might have longer time commitments if you procrastinate on the blog post and news article.

Grading Scheme: Not sure what you mean by this exactly, but for what it's worth the class is not curved and does not really focus on grades. The course syllabus outlines the exact rubric (point by point breakdown) for every assignment so the grading schemes are very clear.

Final Project: The blog post and news article. Optionally, you can choose to make a video instead of the news article. Even though this is technically the final project, all assignments in the course are directly related to this project so it's not like you have to do the whole thing at the end of the semester.

How is ENGIN 185: the Art of STEM Communications? In particular, any of the below information would be very helpful!

  • Webcasted?
  • What you learn.
  • Workload
  • Grading scheme
  • What is the final project (if there is one)?
